title: CTRL0000061475 - Transcribed Interview of Jean Lavin, (April 6, 2022)

data.text: JANUARY 6TH ATTACK ON THE U.S. CAPITOL,
The interview in the above matter was held via Zoom, commencing at 4:37 p.m.
For the SELECT COMMITTEE TO INVESTIGATE
THE JANUARY 6TH ATTACK ON THE U.S. CAPITOL:
This is a transcribed interview of Ms. Jean Lavin
conducted by the House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack on the
United States Capitol pursuant to House Resolution 503.
And at this time, I'd ask the witness to please state your full name and spell your
So this is a staff-led interview.
although I don't see any at this time.
And on the Webex with me today is
Members might come in and ask questions,
At this time, could counsel please state your name for the record?
Well, there is other lawyers, too, as well.
Judge Howell in the District of Columbia.
I'm from the Federal Defender's Office
I represent Ms. Lavin in her case that is pending before
So there is an official reporter transcribing the record of this interview.
wait until each question is completed before you begin your response, and we will try to
wait until your response is complete before we ask our next question.
The stenographer cannot record nonverbal responses, such as shaking your head,
so it's important that you answer each question with an audible, verbal response.
if I see you, you know, nodding yes or shaking no, I'll just, you know, note it for the record
And, in terms of talking over each other, especially with the virtual, it's very hard
for the stenographers to hear, so we'll do our best to wait for you to finish your answer.
And we do ask that you provide complete answers based on your best
If the question is not clear, which it might be, please just ask for
And, if you do not know the answer, please simply say so.
So I want to go through a couple of points here.
First, it's important that you understand that this interview is voluntary.
time you would like to stop speaking with us, that is your choice.
point you need to discuss something with your attorney in private, please just let us
know, and we'll take a break so you can have that conversation with Mr. Willson.
Second, this interview is not under oath.
But, because this is a formal
congressional investigation, you are obligated under Federal law to tell the truth, the
same as if you were speaking to the FBI or the Department of Justice.
deliberately provide false information to Congress.
false information could result in criminal penalties for false statements.
Third, you are not obligated to keep the fact of this interview and what we discuss
You are free to tell whomever you wish that you met with us, including the
prosecutor or judge on your case, or you can tell no one at all.
Fourth, the select committee is separate and independent from the Department
Justice is not a partner with the select committee in our investigation.
We have no involvement with the prosecutions, and the Department of
The select committee also is not a party to your criminal case, and is not agreeing
to submit anything on your behalf to the judge on your case, nor can we make any
representation whether, if you tell the judge that you met with us, that the judge will be
more favorable to you during sentencing.
Fifth, we have agreed with Mr. Willson not to share the substance of what you say
with the Department of Justice prior to your sentencing.
enforcement was unaware of, or if we had reason to believe you lied during this
interview, then we would be obligated to tell the Department of Justice or another
If you told us about evidence of a crime that we thought law
And, if you tell the judge that you met with us, please just understand that they
may -- that they might -- sorry -- that that may prompt questions from the judge about
what you said and whether it is consistent with your prior statements and acceptance of
And, if the judge starts asking questions, we may get asked to respond
And, just logistically, if you need a break, whether for comfort or to discuss
something with Mr. Willson, just let us know.
off camera and mute so that you can have whatever conversations you need to or do
whatever that you need to do.
And there are several people who might be asking questions.
are asking questions at the same time, please just, you know, let us know that you cannot
hear or cannot understand what we're saying, and I'll take the time to repeat the
And the same goes for if you just don't understand a question that one of us
So we'll just start off with a little bit of your background.
I am also -- I grew up in Connecticut, so Hamden, Connecticut, if you know it.
-- how long have you lived there?
I'm a lineman with the local telephone company in Connecticut.
I think you said lineman, so --
Just -- you don't have to give the complete address.
And what is your educational background?
And what do you do for a living?
Can I let them out, please?
Your dogs sound just like my shepherd.
So have you had other careers besides working with the telephone company?
I was a meat cutter at one time in a supermarket.
So we're going to move on and start talking a little bit about -- we're going to talk
about two time periods, and first will be from President Trump's election in 2016 up until
moving forward about the November period until we get to January 6th, and so just to
give you a little frame of reference.
And then we'll ask some more specific questions
So, throughout President Trump's term, how would you describe your level of
I did attend one rally while he was in office.
I didn't campaign for him, but I
Would you say you paid a lot of attention to politics, or not so much?
During the 2016 to 2020 term of President Trump, were you
And thinking about that time period, do you remember what
sources of information you relied on?
Ms. Lavin, did you nod yes to my last question about whether you
were -- paid a lot of attention to politics between 2016 and 2020?
And what sources of information did you rely on to pay attention to politics during
And on Face book, were you following specific groups, or were you following
Was that -- was that local news?
Which news organizations did you pay particular attention to?
Any others that you can remember?
And, in terms of -- you mentioned Facebook obviously.
Was that after the 2020 election that you used Parler?
You ever hear of a website called TheDonald.Win?
So would you say that Facebook was your primary social media site for news?
And do you remember if you followed President -- former
President Trump on social media during the lead-up to the 2020 election?
Did you follow him also after the 2020 election?
And that was just on Face book?
In terms of following him, do you mean, like, she liked his page and
got feeds, or just would generally see what was out there and, you know, read the
Because follow means something to me that it might not mean to her.
In terms of follow, did you affirmatively, I guess, like or whatever you have
to do to follow President Trump's feed so that his feed specifically showed up, or his posts
And did you also see friends -- sorry -- friends posting, like reposting
Well, did you pay particular attention when the former President posted?
During that window of time, the 4 years when he was the
The window of time for the first 4 years, did you pay particular attention to
Did you find that you paid more attention to his posts after the
And then, in terms of -- so that will move -- I'm not going to ask about pre-2020
election anymore, so now the time period will be between the 2020 election and
So, right after the general election in 2020, did you believe that the election had
been stolen from former President Trump?
Do you remember what made -- what fed into your belief that the election
Things that I saw on TV and on the internet.
Were there specific people who posted things that made you think that the
So you don't remember a specific news organization that influenced your
Now, were your friends posting about the election having been
So what about those posts, if you can remember, influenced your belief that
The fact that some of the voting places had shut down at certain times.
There was video of people that were supposed to oversee being removed.
under tables, things that I had heard about ballot harvesting.
There were tubs of ballots that were brought out from
So you heard stories that had been circulating about possible bad
behavior on election night, it sounds like?
Now, I think my colleague,_ had a couple of questions, and I
So these are -- as far as I think, they might be from before
And I'll start at the election and kind of work
my way backwards a little bit, if that's all right.
And it's nice to meet you, Ms. Lavin.
So, building o n - s prior points about the belief in a stolen election,
I'd be interested in have you expand on that just a little bit more.
So could you explain to us how you thought the election was stolen?
mentioned polling places being closed specific times.
What do you think -- what did you
I don't know for sure, but it seemed very suspect.
And the things you were reading about, the suspect activities in the election,
was it concentrated in particular geographic areas, this suspicious activity?
It probably did at the time, but I don't remember which --
Just trying to get a fuller understanding of kind of what
motivated folks and how folks were thinking at the time.
So zooming out a little bit more from the election itself, you were talking earlier to
- a b o u t your support for President Trump throughout his time in office, and so I
wanted to ask you more generally:
Why did you support President Trump?
He seemed to be the leader we needed at the time, and --

-- I believe that he was what we needed.
Jean, how long have you been pretty much voting Republican?
And were there particular issues that you thought he was the leader for?
Can I interject a little bit?
One thing that I think I know that helps.
That -- I think that's an important
You froze up a little bit there for me, but your entire life,
Ms. Lavin, I wanted to see if you had any response to that question about

Well, it's the issues that are in the news today -- immigration, inflation.
Without President Trump in office, they've -- they've exploded.
And were there particular threats that you saw throughout the course of the
Trump presidency that animated your support for the President leading into the 2020
What exactly do you mean, threats?
However you want to understand that.
individuals that you believed were posing a threat to the country that you saw
The riots caused by Black Lives Matter, for one.
The violence created by Black Lives Matter, the burning of cities, the beating
of people, the killing of people, innocent business owners.
So I take it that you saw many of the protests in summer 2020 as veering
And what's your general view on the Black Lives Matter movement as it

Are we getting a little far afield here?
I mean, just -- I'm just going
what Trump thinks about the Black Lives Matter, I can see that being important, but I'm
If it's what does Trump think, or what's her understanding of
-- in terms of the list of questions and topics that I was expecting
based on my conversations with people other than yourself, this whole 4 years

discussed as one of the things we're going to discuss today.
I appreciate the social science that's going on here and trying to,
like, understand why people think what they do, and I think that's important.
know, I'll tell you that Ms. Lavin is a long-time supporter of law enforcement.
a -- I don't want to put words in her mouth, but I would say she's a Blue Lives Matter
person in terms of, you know, how she views things.
And obviously the summer of 2020 -- certainly in some cities, there was some

about more rather than just recounting every political view that she has.
So, you know, what the motivations for that, I guess, is a bigger question,
So I appreciate that point, and I think that --
-- these questions are meant to lead back into the post-election
whether it be antifa or others, were motivating factors for folks who ended up

And obviously there has been quite a lot of conversation about how threats,

And so, I hope that that makes sense.
period before the election, that's where our interest lies.

to that is probably going to be no, but, you know -- but, you know, that's sort of what we

to sort of foreground those questions as they come up.
make that clear enough when we chatted.

believed -- you know, she supported Donald Trump, and she went there to support her

And I think that's, you know, just as far as Mr. Glick is asking.

influenced how you were feeling as the election happened, and then after as the election

You both were being very respectful.
I'm probably the one that's difficult,
but in terms of -- you know, are we going to review every political angle on this in the

So, with that, why don't we try another question.

We'll go back on the record.

do you want to have -- do you have some follow-up there?
I think we can return to some of these questions once we get to

You mentioned that you came to believe that the election was stolen.

remember when that belief set in?
In terms of post-election activity, did you participate in any activities, not including

So you didn't gather any affidavits for a campaign or for a lawsuit or anything like

Ms. Lavin, did you donate to any groups that were making arguments about
election fraud following the 2020 election and before January 6th?
And then I have one question that I forgot to ask.
again, but it's right before the election.
Were you seeing on social media posts before the election about alleged voter
fraud issues or concerns about election security?
So why don't you -- we're going to talk a little bit about why you decided to go to

Washington, D.C., for the January 6th rally.
Did anything that President Trump say influence your decision to go to

I wanted to hear my President speak.
So where did you learn that he would be speaking?
And were you hoping that being in Washington, D.C., on January 6th
I'm not sure it would have done anything other than show my support for

But what part of his Presidency were you trying

So you're there to support your President, but in what

specific issue that you were there to support the President about?
I was hoping that the activities that I didn't feel were on the level would
■■■I( do you mind if I ask a question?
Were you in D.C. or did you come to D.C. to protest the election result in
So you wanted to hear former President Trump speak about the election
To hear my President speak at his rally.
I didn't care what he spoke about.
done previous times in different locations.
speak, and I wanted to see him.
I wanted to hear him at his rally, like I've

I knew that would be brought up.
And that was of interest of you?

But I just want to talk with her for a second off the record, off of

And then, also, if you want to
I'm not sure if that's something to do.
So is it okay if she disconnects and then reconnects?
I think that's -- that should be fine.
And I'm just going to mute myself and step away from mine.

We'll go off the record and come back in 5 --
And I believe we were talking about sort of your motivations for going to
I know you had mentioned -- you mentioned

What was the everything that you were talking about?
You mentioned when I asked you about what you were hoping would come

The inconsistencies with the voting procedures and what I saw on the news

In terms of information about January 6th, you mentioned hearing about it on the
Were you talking to friends about it on social media?
Is that how you learned about who would be speaking besides

So were you following any specific groups on social media that were talking
And then how did you decide to come to Washington, D.C.?
I saw a post on Facebook of a woman who was running a bus trip to
Washington to hear the President speak.
where the bus was meeting, and what time to be there.
Do you remember who this woman was?

And so this was a bus.
We got to D.C. after the President was done speaking.
Most of the people's phones were dying.
And what time did you get to D.C.?
Were you following the speech along on the bus?
So I was unable to see most of it.
Did you hear any of it?
Do you remember which parts that you heard?
So you didn't hear President Trump -- or did you hear

Was anyone on the bus talking about his speech when you were going
And no one was playing it loudly enough for you to hear on the bus?
So when you all did get to D.C., do you remember where you were let off the bus?
It was not where the speech had taken place.
Hordes of people walking towards the Capitol.
It was much closer to the
And what did you see when you got off the bus?
And what were your thoughts when you saw this?
I didn't know what was going to take place.
Not hearing the speech, not knowing what was going to proceed afterwards,
But you saw this group of people.
Why did you want to join them?
So we followed the crowd, got caught up in the crowd.
Was the crowd saying anything when you got caught up in it?
Not that I could hear in particular, no.
So what made you think it was a crowd that you wanted to join?
Because they all had Trump signs or some kind of paraphernalia that
Do you have a sense of what time it was that you got off the bus?
And was your phone still working at this time or was it dead?
So were you communicating with anybody while you were walking to the
Did you talk to anybody in the crowd once you got there?
And I think, Jean, we could say timing-wise that it was probably
before 2 o'clock that you got off the bus, right, given what we know about some other
And I know you were with your daughter, and I appreciate that you're telling
us that you were talking to her.
But I'll be more clear next time if I mean outside of your
daughter if I have another question like that.
Did you bring anything with you from the bus besides your clothes and the phone?
We didn't know what the weather would
And I had a sign with me.
Do you remember what the sign said?
Do you remember why you picked seven?
I believe the count was seven States that were in dispute over the results.
When you say in dispute, who was disputing the results?
I was from what I saw on the news.
Do you remember which seven States they were?
Not at this time, I do not.
So which news organizations were telling you that seven States were
Network news, local news, Facebook, peers.
And I'm sorry to be seemingly pedantic and sort of annoying about this
word, but when you say dispute, was that your own personal view that the count was not
okay, or was it the idea that it was still unclear who had won?
It was still unclear who had won.
And that's according to what you read or saw and your views of the States?
And were you aware at this time that all seven of those States had certified
the vote, the electoral count, the vote, on December 14th already?
Yes, but I still questioned it.
So, again, disputed not meaning whether there was a dispute in the
States, but a dispute in your view that you didn't think that the vote was correct?
So I guess let's talk a little bit about what happened when you got to the Capitol.
Do you remember what it was like walking up?
And what was going on around you?
There were lots of people with signs, with flags.
So you didn't see any violence whatsoever?
And I guess you were walking, according to Mr. Willson's estimate, you were
Not walking to the Capitol, no.
probably walking up to the Capitol around 2 o'clock or so.
Were you hearing loud noises at that time?
Such as, like, bangs or sounds like explosions?
So, in your view, what were those bangs?
But did you think this crowd was peaceful?
Did you see tear gas floating around anywhere?
So, during that time, just if you can remember what you were -- what was going

I did not know what it was.
I couldn't see if it was a dispute among people or if it was worse.
So I guess, then, why did you keep going through this big crowd?
The bangs happened after we were already packed up against the Capitol.
I didn't hear any bangs as we were walking to it.
Capitol, we were packed in like sardines, that's when I heard the bangs.

There was no no-trespassing signs that I saw.
There were so many people that, if it were there, it wasn't well seen, or seen at all.
Jean, I want to ask you a question that might help them a
And, frankly, it's important that I know it.

only been to Washington, D.C., twice before this?
Once we were already close to the
And, when you were approaching the Capitol, is it fair to

Only when I left the Capitol and walked around did I realize that that
was what I was walking to afterwards, was the center.
what side of the Capitol I was on at all.
I didn't -- I had no bearings on
Because I know -- the evidence is that you went up the

And, when you climbed the bike rack that's been turned

I don't know if that helps, but --
Well, just in terms of the timing then, Ms. Lavin, as you explained, you get
What was your perception of what was going on at that time?
I could see some police, and I assumed that the bangs I was hearing was
I saw some people in the crowd who might have been tear-gassed,
but now they were on a stretcher with people helping to try to get them through the

So, at that point, did you think you were in a peaceful crowd?
Yes, because I think the people who were injured were injured because of
the police who were shooting whatever it was.
I only -- I can't say I assumed it was tear
I don't -- I've never had tear gas before, so I don't know what it was like previous to
But I think you mentioned, or Mr. Willson mentioned earlier,
So why do you think that the police were using whatever,
pepper balls, or what was going on at that time?
I'm just trying to get you to think back at that time.
and you said you still thought the crowd was peaceful, I'm trying to understand why you
would think it was peaceful if there's bangs and tear gas and people on stretchers?
I didn't see people in the crowd doing anything that was violent.
But why -Ms. Lavin, would you agree that the crowd was pretty rowdy?
mean, peaceful suggests that we're all holding hands and singing a song or something.
I didn't see any of that.
But I didn't see anybody punching anyone else or pushing, shoving.
So, I'll just represent to you, you went -- we read your court

through the door, like 10 to 12 minutes.
That is very soon after the first people actually get

rack and making their way towards the doors.
But I didn't see the actual
violence or how the doors were broken when it happened.
Well, not behind the crowd, but behind the people who did that damage.

And what did you think the people were rushing to do?

I wasn't participating in the rush, but I was kind of in the middle of it.

Like we're sort of changing modes a little bit.
chanting going on of people saying stuff.
some point in this process into more of the protest mode.

about the inside of the building.

I had never been inside before.

Well, the people on stretchers were in the crowd.
him CPR on a stretcher and another person trying to part the crowd to get them through.

wanted to see the building, but was there another reason that you wanted to stay in the

It was curiosity to a degree.
If it came to me, I got away from it.
I had no issue with the police, nor do I to
And there was one point when you're in the building where, I don't

So -But you saw no law enforcement warning you against entering the

Just the roar of the crowd.

I want to help your memory a
I mean, there was, like, "Stop the steal."

And so I'll just ask specific phrases, then.
I don't know what their intention was.
